text:
Metropolitan Avenue, north side, opposite Seventieth Avenue (known also as Ursula Place and Herrick Avenue). This set of 3 views shows the home of Jeronus Vanderveer. John and Walter Vanderveer were the owners in 19E3 while one Weeden was the occupant. Michael Vanderveer who settled in Newtown in 1810 was born in Flatbush in 1777. He married Martba Vandervoort of Newtoxn. His son Henry Suvdam was born in 1812 in the old koose that stood across the road from his latter residence, which was on the w:st side of Trotting Course Lane just south of Metropolitan Avenue. The son, Henry Suydam, married Sarah J. (Burroughs) Rapelje in 1807. George W. Vandorveer was born in the old family homestead in Newtown in 1842. He married in 1848 Mary Whitson of that place. Charles Boerur: Vanderveer (1796. 1879) owned a thirty-six acre farm at Middle Village. His son 'eronus purchased about 1871 a sixty acre one at the same place. After his fathrs death he, Jeronus, acoufred bia fatkerw farr.. Other owners of this house ere E. Randall, 188O7;H. Needen, 1873; and J. Vanderveer, in 1896. Views 2 and 3 are viewed
east and west respectively.
1922
Views 2a:3: October 1923.
Eugene L. Armhroster Collection

Views 2a:3: October 1923.

Metropolitan Avenue, north side, west from Sevenntieth Ave-ue (forrcrly Herrick Aveue),showing in four views in the foreground the house and outbuildings of J. Vanderveer. In view No. 1 in the background is seen the home of Gol. Eunt. Vie.s S,3, and 4 shows the store barn of the Vanderveer family which was erected in 1850. IIn the 1929 Queens Atlas the buildings seen in these views no longer apbear. For more data concerning the Vanderveer house see views located as the north side of Metropolitan Avenue
opposite Seventieth Avenue.
October 1923
View 2:  April 1923
Views 3e4: 1922
Pgene L. Armbruster Collection
